title: 108_hr3512
content: The "Rural Health Training Incentive Act" is a demonstration program to encourage health professionals to practice in rural areas. It amends the Public Health Service Act to implement programs for this purpose. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may award grants to 5 accredited schools of medicine or nursing to conduct a program encouraging health professionals to practice in rural areas. Funds can be used for developing new programs, improving existing ones, strengthening training systems, and expanding rural training networks. The Secretary may award grants to 5 accredited schools of medicine or nursing for rural training programs. Priority is given to schools with regional consortiums in family medicine and nurses in multiple states. The Secretary prioritizes accredited schools of medicine or nursing with rural training programs lasting at least 2 months and a comprehensive approach to addressing health profession shortages in rural areas. Non-Federal contributions of at least 50% of program costs are required for grant eligibility. The Secretary requires non-Federal contributions of at least 50% of program costs for grant eligibility. Contributions can be in cash or in kind, excluding Federal Government assistance. Grants are awarded for a 3-year period to accredited schools of medicine or nursing with rural training programs. The Secretary requires non-Federal contributions of at least 50% of program costs for grant eligibility. Grants are awarded for a 3-year period to accredited schools of medicine or nursing with rural training programs. Schools of nursing must be accredited by specific organizations for certain programs. A report on the effectiveness of the demonstration programs in addressing health care professional shortages in rural areas must be submitted to Congress within 6 months after the end of the 3-year period. $20,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2005 to 2007 for this section.
